heisig_chinese_memo: Pictograph of the number 2.  Also since this will be called 'hook' or 'fishhook' when used as a primitive we can say - it will only take a second to catch a fish with this hook.
heisig_story: The kanji shown here actually represents the "second" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are "pure," "tasteful," "quaint," and - get this! - fish guts. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (ãŠã¤). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.

humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The original meaning of the Jiajin text has not been finalized. Xu Shen believes that the shape grows like vegetation. "Shuowen": "B, like a spring tree, the yin is still strong, and the yin is still strong, and the second is also. Agree with ä¸¨. B inherits A, like a human neck. All members of B follow B." Dong Lianchi think about the original meaning of the curl, " chaotic " character from " B " to increase significantly its Siniu chaos curl intended. Wu Qichang thought it was like a knife. Ming Yishi and Li Xiaoding believed that " Yi " and "Shouwen" " ğ¡¿¨ " were a variant of the same character, like a small stream of water. "Said Wen": "ğ¡¿¨, the water is small. "Zhou Li": "The craftsman is a ditch, five inches wide, two ã­’ are coupling. One coupling is cutting, wide and deep, which is called ğ¡¿¨, double ğ¡¿¨ It is called sui, Beisui said ditch, Beisui said æ´«, and Beixu said å·œ. "All the genus of ğ¡¿¨ is from ğ¡¿¨. ğ¤° (ç”½), the ancient prose ğ¡¿¨ from Tian Congchuan. ç•, seal script ğ¡¿¨ from Tian, the sound of dogs. Six ç•Itâ€™s one acre.â€ None of the above statements are corroborated, but Li Xiaodingâ€™s statement is more in line with the font. The character " Zhao " in the oracle bone inscriptions is like two people running away from each other. Between the two people, there is both " water " and a tune of pen. It can be seen that water can be written with a pen.

Qiu Xigui pointed out that the ten heavenly stems in the sequence are the most commonly used characters in ancient times and undoubtedly have an extremely long history. The meaning of these glyphs is difficult to explain, and examples of the same or extremely similar shapes can be found in the signs of the late primitive society. The four characters " A ", " B ", " Ding ", and " Kui " in the ten days dry are very likely to be drawn from this symbol in Chinese characters.

The Jiajin inscriptions are all used as the name of the heavenly stems, and the ancients used the heavenly stems to record the days. "Tunnan" 4286: "Yiyou Divination", which means divination on Yiyou Day. Sanshi Pan: "Only Wang Jiuyuechen (in) Yimao" means that Zhouli Wang Jiuyue, the time is on the day of Yimao. It is also used as the temple name of the ancestors, kings, and concubines of the Yin dynasty, such as "Zu Yi", "Father Yi", etc., "Collection" 34050: "Cai (Zai) and (Zu) Yi Zong" refers to the ancestral temple in Zu Yi. Zha Fu Yi Ding: "Zha (Zha) Father Yi Zun Yi" means a bronze ware used to worship Father Yi. Also used as a name, Zeng Hou Yi Ding: "Zeng Hou Yi". It means that the princes of Zeng are named B.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period were used as the heavenly stems to record the day, and "Baoshan Chujian" slip 36: "Yisi Day". Also borrowed to refer to someone, "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Legal Questions and Answers" Jan 10: "A steals a money and goes to the room B, and B fjue, asks B's argument, can (what) is (also)? No matter." It means that A steals a piece of money and goes to B's house , B did not notice, how should B be treated? It should not be a crime.
humanum_short_description_en: The shape of the suspicious water flow in the Jia Jin inscription (Ming Yishi, Li Xiaoding) The word " B " was borrowed as the name of a heavenly stem from a long time ago. It is the second digit of the heavenly stem and is also used to indicate the second order.

heisig_comment: * We will keep fishhook as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.

Heisig: The kanji shown here actually represents the "second" position in the old Chinese zodiac, which the Japanese still use as an alternate way of enumeration, much the same way that English will revert to Roman numerals. Among its many other meanings are "pure," "tasteful," "quaint," and - get this! - fish guts. Since it is a pictograph of a fishhook, it should not be hard to associate it with the key word.
* We will keep fishhook as the primitive meaning. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the kanji. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape. And when it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted and it is stretched out and narrowed, all for reasons of space and aesthetics. Examples follow.
Chinese: Pictograph of the number 2. Also since this will be called 'hook' or 'fishhook' when used as a primitive we can say - it will only take a second to catch a fish with this hook.
koohii1: This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.
koohii2: You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its fish guts silly!

Qiu Xigui pointed out that the ten heavenly stems in the sequence are the most commonly used characters in ancient times and undoubtedly have an extremely long history. The meaning of these glyphs is difficult to explain, and examples of the same or extremely similar shapes can be found in the signs of the late primitive society. The Jiajin inscriptions are all used as the name of the heavenly stems, and the ancients used the heavenly stems to record the days. Radicals: ä¹™  (nose)
Meaning Mnemonic
Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget!
Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
Reading Mnemonic
If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (ãŠã¤). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.
Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.
